reviewText:
My gosh did I have a good time with this game! The platforming in this game I will admit is quite simple, but enjoyable nonetheless. The game is presented in a 2-D format, and the gimmick is that you can flip the view of the world you inhabit 90 degrees at a time, but we'll talk about that later. The atmosphere alone got me spending quite a few hours on this game. Quite a bit more than I should have. You go through sweet grassy plains, to a graveyard, a village with another race of people that have really large heads, and sewers. Though, I never even got to the sewers, because you needed a key to acess it, and I was too lazy to backtrack to find a key.

The plot itself is bland, but the idea of it is that you are Gomez, a little pale boy from a village bias about the non-existence of cubes. That is until the town elder tells you in his incredibly broken English that you are about to embark on an adventure. Then, a floating yellow cube appears, and goes by the name of the Hexahedron. It starts talking in a weird language that is very hard to understand, but we'll go over that in a little while.

Once it is finished talking, he'll give you a magical fez to wear, which gives you the ability to flip the 3-D dimensions to view another side of your 2-D world. After you begin toying with flipping dimensions, the Hexahedron will start to shake in a jerky spasm. Flip the world enough times, and he'll shatter into a bunch of tiny shards. THe game will reboot as if your computer crashed, and your adventure begins to collect the 32 cubes that make up the Hexahedron, to stop Gomez's world from falling apart.

I have covered the majority of this games' positives, but really, you are probably reading this to see the faults.
The first thing you'll notice after looking at your world map, is that there's a lot of space to cover on your map. By the time you are done the game, your map is going to look like a 3-D model of your computer's motherboard. And if navigating the map was too hard for you, you're not going to have a good time back-tracking. I know I didn't need to backtrack really, but if you neglect getting a lot of the cube pieces in a given area and moving onto another portion of the game, you are really going to regret it.
While were on the subject of backtracking, do you remember how I stated that Gomez's world is falling apart? I probably should have also mentioned that space is starting to rip. As you venture through the game, you'll notice these floating black holes that kill you if you touch them. Going forward, they're not a big issue. But backtracking? You might as well be climbing a mountain made of wet bar soap. I know that if you're lucky, they'll disappear if you re-enter the room, but my gosh, they are like trying to get away from that mean, annoying kid on the playground.
I know that even with the black holes, you can still progress with some challenge, but their existence is not a pleasant taste in your mouth.
The worst thing though, is the language. In order to complete some puzzles, you need to read a button order presented in tetronimos, but in order to understand the button order, you have to turn your head 90 Degrees to the left, which is not enjoyable in any aspect. Phil Fish, you're a great guy, but if yopu do change your mind and do end up creating Fez 2, (Which would be awesome.) make the language somewhat understandable! Some of the character dialogue is impossible to read, even with some kind of chart!
Even though I had a good go with this game, you are not going to walk away from your computer with a smile on your face if are not patient. But if you can come out on the other side of the backtracking and black holes, I do believe you will eventually forget the agony, and stop to look at the beutiful scenery this game has in stor for you, or it's truly moving sounds.
That's why, my final verdict for this game... is an 8 out of 10. I really do hope you check out this game and see how you do. and try to re-create the Hexahedron completely out of Anti-Cubes if you can plow through the flaws!

I recommend this game to players in-between casual and intermediate. Have a good playthrough!

reviewText:
Awesome platformer that doesn't make the player break several controllers.
Interesting idea about 2D/3D duality gives some new experience. There're also several zones with different style and endemic features so the game is NOT about using the new trick several hundred times.
It was intended for consoles, but I've played it on PC and controls are fine.
The picture, music and the whole process are mostly relaxing. There're not so many places where precise timing or rush through entire level are required. Instead, there're puzzles. Plenty of them, using sound, time, colour and so on. Prepare a notepad and a pencil!

reviewText:
As far as I've played so far, I love it.  I find it unique and creative, as not many games out there are both 2D and 3D. The elements and controls are easy to handle, however many of the puzzles are difficult to solve.  There aren't many clues out there, and the ones that are are very hard to translate or solve.  Navigation through worlds is a little bit frustrating as well, as you have to constantly refer back to the map in order to see the next screenshot of the area you need to go to next to pass through.

And I'm not even going to start on the black holes............................ x_x

But overall, yes. I do very much enjoy this game and recommend it to anyone else who shows even the slightest interest. It'll keep you busy for hours.

reviewText:
Puzzle-Platformer with a different perspective on the genre *huehue*.

So, i recommend this one, but i got mixed opinions on it, but first, a descprition:
This is hard to explain, so better watch a bit of gameplay....
Done? No? Ok, so in this game you climb and jump up and down buildings/landscapes and get over obstacles on a 2d dimension, but you do it by spinning the 3D room and walking on sides in a 2D manner. While surfaces always combine to new possible ways because they line up through the new perspective.
Doesn't make any sense? Yeah, I said its hard to explain...  go watch some gameplay.
AAAAAAnyway, review:
This game has a very unique idea, and executes it well with barly no glitches/control problems at all. You get used to the whole idea of swtiching perspective really quick, and the world is designed in creative ways.
The plattforming is mostly easy though, and the puzzles so far where either very easy, or unsolveable (or maybe im an idiot?). But I guess some puzzles are solved over longer time-frames torwards the end of the game, as this plattformer is actually a very open expierience in terms of world design. Instead of hopping through level for level (aka mario bros way of doing things), you actually are supposed to roam around and discover and explore, and maybe revisit some of the areas.
And the game world is huge, really.
Aside from that, it doesn't look like there is much happening, its exploring, puzzles and jumping, no fights or anything like that, so if you looking for action plattformers, this is not for you.
For me the game got a bit boring after a while, maybe the game-world is just to big for my attention span...
But if you a really into exploring and less for action, this game is your go to game.
'nuff said.

reviewText:
It is an incredibly beautiful game and has a nice feel to it. The level design is wonderful and doesn’t make it completely based on timing like most other platformers and is instead based on turning the world around until you can find a way to go further.

The only down side of this game is that it’s a little boring sometimes because it’s a rather slow game, but I guess it depends a little on what mood you are in.

reviewText:
It's so hard to talk about why this is a great game without spoiling any of its magic.

I suppose I'll just say that while exploring it, I actually began to keep a physical notebook on it, containing sketches, notes, theories, translations and doodles on over 30 pages.

I had never done anything like that before. FEZ inspired me to do it. It was some of the best fun I've ever had playing a game, and reading through my notebook again still makes me happy.

Please enjoy FEZ.

reviewText: Before I played FEZ, I expected it to be a relaxing, slow-paced, pixelated nostalgia trip platformer with an interesting 3D mechanic. And that's exactly what it was, for the first few hours.... What I was not expecting was to cover my desk with notes, madly scrambling to write down in-game clues and decryption codes to hidden messages for days on end, slowly going insane as I became more and more emersed in this bizarre world.\n\nWhile it appears simple and flat, the story in FEZ has surprising depth (Eh? Get it? Because of the turning thing? Oh, nevermind.) It's halfway a parody of everything 8-bit and old school, and halfway a crazy world of its own. The world is vast and beautiful, the puzzles range from simple to complex and involved, and the music is wonderful. Overall a great game. If you're planning on playing it all the way through (don't be fooled by false endings...), be prepared to go slightly mad.

reviewText: A great twist on the classic platformer. There's a whole lot to love about FEZ, such as the ingenious level design and mechanics, great music and overall look and feel. It doesn't take itself too seriously, yet there are heaps of secrets which you'll be hard-pressed to discover all on your own without the help of Google. There are some great attention to detail, and low specs required are also a bonus for those with an old rig. I haven't tested, but I'm willing to bet it will run just fine on an Intel HD 3000 at around 768p.\nIt's not perfect, with a world map that is difficult to navigate, few (and I mean very few) levels which resort to clichéd design, and general antagonism to keyboard-and-mouse setup. It's not by any means unplayable and it can be done just fine with a classic setup, but still it was the first time ever I've played any game and wished for a controller. Fair enough, it's ported from XBLA and all, but even simple things like being able to continue using my arrow keys to look around in first-person mode would have made a world of difference.\nSmall niggling things aside, it made a platformer fan out of me, and I'm sure it will for a lot of other people.

reviewText:
Alright first let me say this. As much as anyone might hate Phil Fish... this game is an absolute MASTERPIECE.

It is a little tad bit boring off the start, but as the game progresses it gets more and more interesting, and at the same time, more and more difficult.

The difficulty of the game is nothing to laugh about, don't underestimate it at first. I found myself looking up guides quite frequent, maybe it is because I'm generally bad at puzzle games, but still, the game gets pretty damn difficult. Hell, the game even incorporates its own language system. It is amazing!

The art and music are a huge selling point though. Fez might be one of the most charming looking pixelated-games I have seen in a LONG TIME. The art is stunning and beautiful. The Music is calm and soothing at point, and fits well with the scene, while at other it is fast and intense to, like I said, again, match the scene.

Probably what makes this game unique from other pixel based platformers, is the game changing mechanic to change your perspective of the world you are exploring. Honestly, without this mechaninc the game would be boring. But it's not. The puzzle are more difficult then you have probably seen in a puzzle game because oft his. It truly does make the game magnificent. Also, let us not forget about the fun first-person view once you continue on to New Game +".

All and all
date: Fez is just a charmingly difficult amazement of a game. Just go buy it now. Like right now. Go. Why are you still here? BUY THE GAME!"

reviewText:
Surprising. Very, VERY surprising. I’ve been quite skeptical about FEZ because I generally haven’t appreciated any Indie platformers. In fact when I started this game, I was almost so certain to call it a disaster blaming the fact that Phil had wasted too much time on the pixel art rather than the gameplay. And I also had this feeling I was going to have an Arkham City type of debate with sauce, because it’s always enjoyable seeing him rage a bit ;P

But no, this game is genuinely worth playing. If you ever enjoyed playing Prince of Persia (on MS-DOS), The Legend of Zelda: Link’s Awakening (on Gameboy) and Tetris (also on Gameboy) with a dash of the infamous Rubik’s Cube (amazingly I solved that after losing the instructions as a kid) then as sauce would say, “You owe it to yourself to buy this game.” … for old times’ sake.

The gameplay is very basic, it follows in the classical “Find the Cheese” that some of the very old games use to implement as a way to aid developers by marking waypoints. For example finding the cheese in Perfect Dark on N64. In this case you need to find cube fragments.

What I really found surprising was the game engine itself. Essentially I’m pretty sure the world is 3D. But you only have 4 side perspectives of the world. It’s easy to figure out, but I have no idea how Phil Fish or Renaud Bédard pieced all the puzzles and level designs together. Because it would be a mind ♥♥♥♥ to program as platforms from 1 side can interchangeably connect to 2 other sides.

I also found the world map fascinating. Initially it looks really messy. But after a few rotations it makes sense and the legends are clearly marked. The learning curve for the usability of this game is incredibly fast and easy to understand. Bonus points for that.

The ending was just astonishing. I highly recommend watching Indie Game: The Movie before attempting to finish this game otherwise you won’t understand the ending (which I reckon is a connection to Phil Fish’s childhood).

I haven’t quite finished the game yet. I’ve done 113% which is the base game. But I think you can go to 200% but it’s mainly finding anti-cubes (which are harder to find than normal cubes) I suspect there’ll be some sort of secret unlock once that’s done. I’d say this is purely for replayability and ya know what, it works …

reviewText:
This is a fun and Very Beautiful 2-D Sidescroller with a 3-D twist (ha, puns!) The platforming is solid, the puzzles range from easy-to-solve platform jumping and translating an alien language trying to understand what it means. Perhaps my favorite aspect of this game is that, although it's a 2-D Sidescroller, it feels like you're exploring an open world. Everything is connected, you can either use the warp portals to make your way back to the beginning, or you can run the whole way back and I consider that impressive! Here's the Pro's and Con's. Pro's: Fun and fluid gameplay, Interesting 3-D mechanic, Great Soundtrack, Challenging Puzzles, and Memorable Areas. Con's: some of the puzzles seem to require a degree in Cryptology, you'll sometimes get very lost with seemingly nowhere to go (albeit this is rare). All-in-all I'd say it's worthy of it's 91 Metascore.

P.S. if you're playing this without a gamepad you may wanna consider changing the controls from the default, other wise you'll be stumbling over yourself for the first hour.

Thanks For Reading! :]

reviewText: I saw this game on a weekend deal for $5 and when I saw that its rating was so high, I couldn't resist giving it a chance. I am quite a big indie game fan especially platformers, but this one felt more like a puzzle. In fact, I'd say it's a perfect combination of an adventure, platformer and puzzle game. The feature mechanic is that you can rotate the world which forces you to constantly visualize in 3D as well as in 2D. It works flawlessly in my opinion. This game has a lot of content for an indie game, not only do you have to collect 32 cubes, you can also collect 32 anti-cubes and unlock a ♥♥♥♥ ton of secrets. The music and visuals are top notch, they fit each other and highly remind me of the indie game SuperBrothers: Sword and Sworcery EP. The only flaw I have with this little gem is that travelling between levels can be a pain if you forgot a secret in a certain room. You cannot teleport to whichever level you want, you must pass through warp holes. It's not so bad since you gotta use the map smartly and it adds gameplay value since you cannot rush to whichever place you want. This game entirely deserves its praise, I'll give it a 90/100. A must for every indie games fan.

reviewText:
This is a pure puzzle platformer down to the bone.
You see there is no combat or real danger in this game, it is pure exploration.

But this is where the game is innovative.

You receive a magical fez that bestows you with the power to change perspectives from 2D to 3D at will.
Use this new power to explore the landscapes and find secrets that were once invisible to you!
It's a really groovy mechanic and the retro-bit graphics really bring the package together nicely.

I recommend it to fans of exploration and pure puzzle platformers.

9/10

reviewText:
A rainbow entirely just became entirely immersed upon every structure in your surroundings. In addition to a cute little guy that likes sleeping when you're not playing for 30 seconds, and this mixes up FEZ. The game consists of a parallel between a 3D and 2D experience like I've never seen before. To successfully accomplish a level, one must be able to solve the puzzle from both the 2D platform, and the 3D level to move forward with the game. Advantages:
Broad and colorful theme.
Smooth gameplay in regards to frames
Storyline was decent

reviewText: Fez is a cute game, with good graphics and the puzzles range from simple to complex. Though the story is very simple, and short, its a good game to play through quickly and easy to perfect. You're taken into different worlds, each with a different atmosphere and a complimentary soundtrack in order to find the 64 pieces of the puzzle. There were moments that were annoying or where you would get lost with the plethora of doors, and some puzzles required you to look up where certain pieces were(unless you know how to read QR codes and hex). The controls can be difficult to adjust to at first, but it becomes reflex quickly, and you learn how to maneuver the mazes easily. Overall, I'd say it was a good game.

reviewText:
It's so hard to talk about why this is a great game without spoiling any of its magic.

I suppose I'll just say that while exploring it, I actually began to keep a physical notebook on it, containing sketches, notes, theories, translations and doodles on over 30 pages.

I had never done anything like that before. FEZ inspired me to do it. It was some of the best fun I've ever had playing a game, and reading through my notebook again still makes me happy.

Please enjoy FEZ.

reviewText: Before I played FEZ, I expected it to be a relaxing, slow-paced, pixelated nostalgia trip platformer with an interesting 3D mechanic. And that's exactly what it was, for the first few hours.... What I was not expecting was to cover my desk with notes, madly scrambling to write down in-game clues and decryption codes to hidden messages for days on end, slowly going insane as I became more and more emersed in this bizarre world.\n\nWhile it appears simple and flat, the story in FEZ has surprising depth (Eh? Get it? Because of the turning thing? Oh, nevermind.) It's halfway a parody of everything 8-bit and old school, and halfway a crazy world of its own. The world is vast and beautiful, the puzzles range from simple to complex and involved, and the music is wonderful. Overall a great game. If you're planning on playing it all the way through (don't be fooled by false endings...), be prepared to go slightly mad.

reviewText:
FEZ is a simple but strangely reflective and philosophical game. Simply because the mechanics and gameplay are nothing beyond a platformer with changes of perspective. In game terms, FEZ is a puzzle game with seemingly little challenge, just being a simple and relatively easy learning curve of platforming mechanics, speed and changing perspective.
That said, the real challenge is to realize that FEZ, from the very start, is a kind of meta-inception, with ambiguous meanings behind every simple mechanic that you must apply in order to solve the puzzles.

To get the full potential, you need to think outside the box and STAY AWAY from guides because otherwise FEZ lose all its splendor.

reviewText:
This is a very glitchy game, though some of the glitches are meant to be there, because the game world is actually supposed to be unstable according to the Fez plot.  Anyway,  the game is a great experience.  I enjoy exploring every nook and cranny of the levels and finding secrets all over the game world.  The levels are very imaginative and well animated.  The pixel art style and orthographic camera rotation behavior work well together.  It is far from perfect, but it is a very unique and engrossing experience.

Pros:
1. Imaginative world and plot.
2. Lovable main character.
3. Loads of secrets and challenging puzzles.

Cons:
1. Some technical flaws hidden well by fake glitches most of the time but the game crashes/freezes/hangs a lot.
2. Some sections of the game can be unnecessarily confusing.
3. Hard to find your way around the game world.

The pros outweigh the cons in my opinion.

reviewText: It boasts a very colorful setting, a mind-blowing mechanic that is great fun at first, plus a mysterious nature that keeps you hungry for more.\n\n...however it lacks the more" part.  Upon backtracking down your 4th tower you'll be wondering where the big point of it all is.  It leaves clues and hints to a story of something long-lost
date: but doesn't deliver on a payoff of any sort.\n\nPuzzles have two varieties: "hop up platforms" and "look up guide on internet".  It doesn't expect you to use logic and puzzle-solving
recommended: but actual decryption skills which I think is beyond the capability of most (including myself).\n\nThe ending was insubstantial
hoursPlayed: and the ending you get for beating all the puzzles is downright offensive.  All in all it is a wonderful display of light and sound...but lacks any meaning behind any of the supposed depth."

reviewText:
Fez was a dissapointment
Going into Fez, I had certain expectations. I expected the game to be polished, to have challanging dimention-based puzzles, and a potentially pretentious story or presentation. After playing the game to the end (or at least the end that I'm willing to tolerate), I have no desire to see what its new game plus has to offer, nor do I care about what I missed. In a puzzle game, if your player feels like this, you failed as a developer.

In Fez, there is a language that you will have to learn if you want to finish the game, or you could just do the sensible thing and look it up on line or you can: spend hours exploring every room, writing everything said in game down out of game, decifering the code using context clues, and eventually figuring out the entire alphabet as well as directions. For some people that may seem life fun, but it's definitly a very small niche. If you like codebreaking, then Fez is a gem. If you want a fun, challanging, or interesting puzzle game, you are out of luck.

As for the puzzles, they were often straight forward if they didn't involve the Fez language. The game was mostly platforming, which I didn't like. The wasn't too much of a challange in figuring out most of the levels in game. There was also little moments of frustration when the mechanics refused to work properly, such as when grabbing on to vines. The game wasn't challanging so much as it was time consuming.

As for the good points, the sound design is well done. The background noise and the music are enjoyable. At times it was relaxing, and at other times, it was a bit unsettling. I enjoyed that at the very least.

To conclude, as a puzzle game, Fez falls flat for me. It's a competent platformer, and (if it's your thing) has an interesting code to crack (if you don't mind that it has already been cracked for several years now and can be found easily online). There are a lot of better puzzle games, puzzle platform games, and games in general.

Also, I figure I should put this in here, I knew nothing of the controvery around Fez's creator. I didn't dislike this game because he made it. I disliked it because it was frusrating, boring, and remarkably unengaging from so many angle (gameplay was unchallanging, the story wasn't interesting, the characters weren't defined or remarkable in any way). Take that as you will

reviewText: A great twist on the classic platformer. There's a whole lot to love about FEZ, such as the ingenious level design and mechanics, great music and overall look and feel. It doesn't take itself too seriously, yet there are heaps of secrets which you'll be hard-pressed to discover all on your own without the help of Google. There are some great attention to detail, and low specs required are also a bonus for those with an old rig. I haven't tested, but I'm willing to bet it will run just fine on an Intel HD 3000 at around 768p.\nIt's not perfect, with a world map that is difficult to navigate, few (and I mean very few) levels which resort to clichéd design, and general antagonism to keyboard-and-mouse setup. It's not by any means unplayable and it can be done just fine with a classic setup, but still it was the first time ever I've played any game and wished for a controller. Fair enough, it's ported from XBLA and all, but even simple things like being able to continue using my arrow keys to look around in first-person mode would have made a world of difference.\nSmall niggling things aside, it made a platformer fan out of me, and I'm sure it will for a lot of other people.

reviewText:
This game is amazing. Not even gonna exaggerate. It's a paper mario-esque platformer, but it can still be coined as original. You are Gomez. You find a fez. You save the universe. That's the game. Some people dislike the game because of the developers, but whatever, just play the game. It's not for everybody without a doubt. The controls are a bit slick, which can make it challenging at times.

Gameplay is pretty good, average platformer with a twist. Can't say too much. My real love for the game is all in the soundtrack and atmosphere, baby. You feel immersed right into the game at times with the phenominal OST. I even bought a copy of it for myself. That's the true strongpoint of the game, though. The atmosphere. Without it, I wouldn't really play it at all.

If you're hesitant to buy it, just wait for a sale. Not sure if I'd fork over $10 considering I don't know how long it will take to beat.

reviewText: How can such an adorable game, filled with love and passion, be made by such a hateful person? I suppose he really is just so serious about game design he fails to acknowledge people's feelings/reactions. It makes me laugh though, how Phil Fish was so hell-bent on making it an XBLA EXCLUSIVE ONLY, because XBOX IS MASTER RACE, then changes his mind(gets his head out of his ♥♥♥, again) and puts it on Steam. I'm glad he did though, I was sorely disappointed when it was announced. It looks so amazing, but it was on XBOX ONLY. Well, now that I got a chance to play it, I've finally gotten to appreciate it, even though I don't appreciate the creator all that much. It's fun, it's challenging, it takes you through a plethora of emotions, it's a game worth playing. Buy it, play it, love it.

reviewText:
It's so hard to talk about why this is a great game without spoiling any of its magic.

I suppose I'll just say that while exploring it, I actually began to keep a physical notebook on it, containing sketches, notes, theories, translations and doodles on over 30 pages.

I had never done anything like that before. FEZ inspired me to do it. It was some of the best fun I've ever had playing a game, and reading through my notebook again still makes me happy.

Please enjoy FEZ.

reviewText:
Childlike wonder floated through me when I played Fez.
Do you remember the first time you were ever absorbed into a videogame as a child?
For me it felt like Zelda and Mario way back in the day.

Behind the retro look and feel lies a fantastic journey, with secrets so grand I didn't even attempt to crack them (it was designed to be broken by the internet in a team effort).
A well designed game if I ever saw one.

Get it together with the soundtrack (listen to it here: http://disasterpeace.com/album/fez), it is a huge part of Fez.
(played it on Xbox360 and double dipped, hence my low playtime)

reviewText: Hard for me to rate this one. It wasn't good enough, gameplay-wise, that I felt compelled to finish, but the design and the effort put into it is laudable, to say the least. There's also something to be said about a game that doesn't urge you to finish it - this game doesn't push you along unwillingly, and I appreciate that. Overall, I have to recommend this because I've never seen anything like it and I just can't get over the core mechanic. Beyond that, it's hard to say how a given individual will enjoy this one.

reviewText:
Wow. Just wow. This game... was certainly not at all what I expected. Taken its development history, and the whole Phil Fish drama and subsequent backlash, I had this game in the back of my mind, labelled as a simple indie platformer.

Still, I wouldn't lose anything for playing it. And I went for it, expecting a pretty platformer.

Several days later, I found myself in a room... papers on the floor, with weird symbols and ciphers on them.



Well, maybe I'm embellishing the story a little bit, but that was the feeling I got from it. And it felt damn good.


Alright. Fez is NOT your traditional game. It's not as much of a platformer as it is a puzzle game. And also not a typical puzzle game. Its final puzzles created a community around the game, everyone trying to solve them as a group for several months. Even now, there are possible mysteries still unknown to most players. And that's not an easy thing to do. I mean... it's the Internet!

I usually like to do a review to fully analyze each aspect of a game, going throught the graphics, music, game mechanics, some design flaws, etc. I'm pretty sure I'll run out of words going on about Fez. So I'll just try to convey what the game did differently from most games, and why you should or should not play it.

I'll give its presentation a brief paragraph. If you're not saturated of the retro, pixel-art look, Fez looks amazing. Despite having a fairly simple visual style, it has a huge attention to detail, and lots of different kinds of areas, each equally impressive. I can't imagine how much work has been put into it, but the final result surely did not disappoint me.
The music is equally good! It's mostly a relaxing kind of chiptunes, with the occasional darker tone. But it's really good, and I might listen to it outside the game, at times. I might also add that they never got repetitive, or just stopped out of nowhere. Everything there flowed perfectly.
Regarding the controls, menus and interface, I didn't have a single issue with it, it had anything I needed.


Onward to the game itself, then!

Superficially, Fez is a 2D platformer with a particular mechanic: the whole world is actually a cube, meaning that you'll have to rotate its 4 faces to get from one place to another, and gather all the collectibles. This mechanic seems more of a novelty (and to a point it is, in terms of simple platforming), but turns out to be more important later on.

There is barely any punishment for falling off platforms, and there's no combat, so Fez isn't a stressing game from an action standpoint.
What you essentially do, is collect Cubes, to open gates. You can either collect an entire Cube from solving a puzzle, or you can gather 8 little pieces that form a single Cube. In the end, if all went well, you'll have collected all 32 Cubes. These can be
gathered by simple puzzling and platforming, a way of casually beating" the game

reviewText: This is the most clever, ambitious and outright gorgeous exploration platformer that I've ever played. With a gigantic beautiful world to explore full of hidden lore and secrets that you can't even imagine and puzzles that actually make you think outside (really outside) the box and plenty of nods and homages to classic gaming.\n\nThere's nothing quite like this game out there, and I doubt there ever will be, it's one of a kind.

reviewText:
One of my personal favorites, FEZ is a fun little Indie game that uses the unique style of 8bit graphics and genuine calm fun.

Pros:
Very calm gameplay
Tight Controls
Soothing Music
Everything is cute
Intersting Environments
Average-level Puzzles
Quick Respawn After Dying
Cons:
Can get lost, but not often
Can get a bit boring after a while
I'll give you a brief summary of the game. You start of with a cute little character (Gomez) that has been given the task to save the world from being destroyed by being placed from a 2D realm to a 3D & 2D realm. Gomez is given a fez by a giant floating yellow hexahedron, which allows him to see the world he once saw only 2D, but now can see both 2D and 3D. However, this causes his entire universe to start falling apart. The player's job is to find cubes around his universe to repair the deteriorating beyond.

This game is basically a calm adventure puzzle game. One has the ability to rotate the world from left to right to get a whole different perspective of the world one is currently in. Since FEZ is based around discovery, rotating the world can allow one to find cubes and get to certain places for new discoveries. It's a very unique way of solving puzzles, it just puts a lot of fun into climbing towers by fixing the view of something that seemed impossible, but from another view, is completely possible.

The gameplay is one controlling Gomez by walking and jumping to different worlds and finding the cubes. There are a lot of them out there, so be prepared to search everywhere.

The music fits the game very nicely with tranquil music that fits the atmosphere of the game and the mood of trying to solve puzzles. It's also quite catchy and just plain fun to listen to.

The controls of Gomez are pretty tight in controlling him. One has WASD to move and Spacebar to jump, but he also can grab ledges and crawl along the walls and vines, leading to some unknown places that one couldn't get to by just walking or jumping.

Fortunately, the not-so-good parts of the game are scarce. One could get lost/frustrated about navigating through many many places of the universe, looking in every corner for a cube. Also, trying to find some cubes in worlds and also trying to find a way to get to said-world can be a bit boring. However, it is enjoyable to search new worlds for cubes and figure out many puzzles with spinning the world around like a top.

All in all, this game is very enjoyable and a really fun puzzle adventure, enjoyable by all.

reviewText:
It's plausible that yes, one day, you too can enjoy the inherent and neo-liberal psychological twist pan adventure that is HP Brown sauce, however today is a review about FEZ. FEZ is a romantic comedy starring David Spade as former KGB Agent turned Kid's Magician, Roy Magestico who develops a huge wand for none other than Leela Loolee personified in the mortal form of Dakota Fanning. Things take a turn when Roy discovers he has inoperable colon cancer during one of his shows, prompting him to move faster than he would otherwise have done in order to obtain his true love.
His obstacle, aside from the aforementioned fatal whimsy of God, is the grizzled and chizzled adonnis, Spadge O'Hoolahan (Ricky Gervais). Spadge is a nasty and selfish man who, despite whopping huge wads of cash, does not entirely understand his own raison d'être, why is Spadge here? What does he do? Spadge is a gamechanger because he runs out of tissues.
The cinematography is. The canted angles and in media res reaks of Tarantino, just without the hair. Patting the rather obese Chilean wombat proves rather obscene when Al Kongo (Roger Moore) is resurrected in the world's first internet streamed bovine intervention.
FEZ fails to recognise the core basics of the mechanic which does not bode well for the industry. The final scene where Spadge and Roy confront each other on a pier somewhere off the coast of Hungary leaves a lot to be desired, let alone the geographical ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥isation of what was once a proud empire. Shirley Bassey gets white girl drunk in the scene before that, not that any of this matters, because of the Deus Ex Machina introduced by young Whopper Cole (The Coca Cola Company) which is that he has a magical laser, sponsored by the power of Coke, which can cure poor David Spade's ♥♥♥♥ or something.
I will be honest, FEZ lost my attention quickly. Was there too much focus on the cancer and not enough on the gazelle straddling the roof of Dakota Fanning's Luxurious and roomy yacht? Why does the restaurant conundrum go unsolved? Where did they find all those badger hats? And, perhaps most importantly, Why? All of the above questions can't be answered by FEZ. It falls short at the first hurdle, losing track of all that is holy.
To conclude, would I agree that FEZ is an entity? I could be convinced. Would I allow my freedom loving American tadpole offspring the right to touch it? Who knows. It is an enigma within an anarcho-syndicalist capital estate hitherto unspoken and unseen by humanity. Is this reviewer craving a piece of edible food? Only just.

reviewText: FEZ... what is it? Well my esteemed review reader FEZ is a puzzle platformer with an amzing twist. The ability to use 3D to your advantages. On the outside this game is a 2D platformer, but with every dimesnion you shift someyhing new appears making the game that much more fun. When I first played this game and turned the dimesnions I couldn't stop changing the dimensions. Another thing to mention is that this game's soundtrack is fantastic and it fits the atmosphere perfectly. Speaking of atmosphere, the atmosphere in this game is fitting and completely engulfes you with is pixelated art stlye and makes you feel that you are jumping from block to block and that you are changing the dimesions. In conclusion, if you are looking for a casual gaming experience and something relaxing then this game is for you!

reviewText: Jesus tapdancing motherloving Christ this game is bad, i have never been so close to dying from a sever case of the borings in my life, why call your self a platforming game if you jumps barely see what you are jumping upon? I managed to beat the first level but my frustration and shouting caused a series of unfortunate events to occur, first my child awoke from my pained exhaultations and began to follow my activity with it's own personal twist of replacing my rage and frenzy into emotions and fear and discontent. Upon this child's screams laying gently upon my wife's morphine laced ears, she realised the situation involved a possible chance of me throwing the Liquid Crystal Display based viewing monitor carefully connected my my hard drive by the large greasy man from PC world who helped set up my computer when my previous failures caused two things, one, my wife's black eye, and two, me having to pay the gentleman to keep quiet and to return wo his home planet of Personal Computers without any mention of his experiences in our dimensional plane. Upon picking up the child she began calling the police in the fear that she would be subject to what i can only describe as a Beltbuckle whirlwind, I couldnt stop her as i usually could because I was too busy trying to figure out if what i was playing was a game or just a poor excue to exploit a gimmick that ends up just confusing the player and not providing anything new to a genre that was once a bastion of difficulty adn challenge, but with the addition of little to no enemies feztakes this genre into a direction that seemed good but was infact a step into uncle bubba's basement full of mystical wonders and restraining equipment.The police arrived promptly given my previous offenses and found the fifteen ankle bracelets that they had assigned to me all lying on the floor in a pattern that spelled out the words 'i fought the law and the law won'. The irony was not lost on me. I am writing this review from prison during my precious few minutes i am allowed on the rec room's computer time sheet. This is all just to pass time of course becausei can expect that my inmate (known only as big jim and i can tell you he is only 5'9 so the operative word 'big' must refer to either his hands or feet, or at least a hope so). The tragedy of this situation is that he wasn't planning on having his way with me until i mentioned that i preferred platformers that utilise enemy placement and difficulty and not just use silly gimmicks to trick people into thinking time and effort was put into a game, but unfortunately big jim disagreed. Well thank you fez, for the impending traumatic experience, i hope you realise just how pathetic you are, at least in my last moments of anal virginity i retain a shred of self respect which is not particularly easy for an abusive husband/father.

reviewText: Probably one of the best games I've ever played. It's very relaxed while still being engaging, with puzzles that you can pop in to, try to solve, give up on and come back to. Yet the satisfaction of actually solving a puzzle, or completing a cube, is immense. It helps that the game is beautiful, with great music and a lovely atmosphere. Plus, the whole perspective thing is really fun, clever and eye-opening. In the least pretentious way possible.\n\nI should probably add that I have by no means completed FEZ, and I'm unlikely to. As amazing as the puzzles are, I don't really have the energy to make notes of three (?) different languages and use them to solve the more difficult puzzles. But I think this game has enough content besides that to make it worth it, so I'd really just say the more complicated stuff that requires more dedication is an added bonus.

reviewText: This game has it's up's and downs, but the thing that makes it shine is the puzzles. The fun really starts when you complete the game. Invisible blocks, cryiptic paintings, an alphabet for the game, sound puzzles, changing your system clock and even scanning QR codes! It's platforming may not be the best, but the puzzles are!

reviewText:
Wow. Just wow. This game... was certainly not at all what I expected. Taken its development history, and the whole Phil Fish drama and subsequent backlash, I had this game in the back of my mind, labelled as a simple indie platformer.

Still, I wouldn't lose anything for playing it. And I went for it, expecting a pretty platformer.

Several days later, I found myself in a room... papers on the floor, with weird symbols and ciphers on them.



Well, maybe I'm embellishing the story a little bit, but that was the feeling I got from it. And it felt damn good.


Alright. Fez is NOT your traditional game. It's not as much of a platformer as it is a puzzle game. And also not a typical puzzle game. Its final puzzles created a community around the game, everyone trying to solve them as a group for several months. Even now, there are possible mysteries still unknown to most players. And that's not an easy thing to do. I mean... it's the Internet!

I usually like to do a review to fully analyze each aspect of a game, going throught the graphics, music, game mechanics, some design flaws, etc. I'm pretty sure I'll run out of words going on about Fez. So I'll just try to convey what the game did differently from most games, and why you should or should not play it.

I'll give its presentation a brief paragraph. If you're not saturated of the retro, pixel-art look, Fez looks amazing. Despite having a fairly simple visual style, it has a huge attention to detail, and lots of different kinds of areas, each equally impressive. I can't imagine how much work has been put into it, but the final result surely did not disappoint me.
The music is equally good! It's mostly a relaxing kind of chiptunes, with the occasional darker tone. But it's really good, and I might listen to it outside the game, at times. I might also add that they never got repetitive, or just stopped out of nowhere. Everything there flowed perfectly.
Regarding the controls, menus and interface, I didn't have a single issue with it, it had anything I needed.


Onward to the game itself, then!

Superficially, Fez is a 2D platformer with a particular mechanic: the whole world is actually a cube, meaning that you'll have to rotate its 4 faces to get from one place to another, and gather all the collectibles. This mechanic seems more of a novelty (and to a point it is, in terms of simple platforming), but turns out to be more important later on.

There is barely any punishment for falling off platforms, and there's no combat, so Fez isn't a stressing game from an action standpoint.
What you essentially do, is collect Cubes, to open gates. You can either collect an entire Cube from solving a puzzle, or you can gather 8 little pieces that form a single Cube. In the end, if all went well, you'll have collected all 32 Cubes. These can be
gathered by simple puzzling and platforming, a way of casually beating" the game
